body: Based on the response code (4.00) I'd say that this is a bug since this is clearly not the client's fault and I agree that this should rather result in a 5.03 being returned to the device.

I guess at some point `.recover(thr -> Future.failedFuture(StatusCodeMapper.toServerError(thr)))` needs to be added to translate the client error (like [here](https://github.com/eclipse/hono/pull/2352/files#diff-1f6a8df336aae67d760da530cc0acc3cd6816c7f8f85647592772f738dc2dccbR94)).

It looks to me as if Artemis has sent a "rejected" disposition here, which will get mapped to a "400 - Bad request" here:
https://github.com/eclipse/hono/blob/cb3fc07228b2c13ebcfcd066c1c265bef16113f3/client/src/main/java/org/eclipse/hono/client/impl/AbstractSender.java#L315-L319

That is also done in `GenericSenderLink#sendMessageAndWaitForOutcome()`.
The general case of translating a "rejected" disposition to a client error still seems valid to me (message got rejected because the client sent an invalid message).
The specific error here however should probably get special treatment. Of course doing product-specific error string matching doesn't look pretty, but I guess matching the Artemis-specific (?) error code "AMQ229102" would be ok here, since both usage of Artemis and this specific error should be quite common.

I would prefer to adapt the HTTP_BAD_REQUEST into 5.03 in case of the AMQ-code for full event-queue.
For me this is similar to the telemetry case 5.03, when too many messages are send in a time period.

@calohmn I would rather not check the error's *description* but the error's *condition* instead. Do you have a setup where you can reproduce the issue? I am asking because we will need to find out, which condition is being set by Artemis in this case. I would guess that it is `amqp:resource-limit-exceeded` but we will need to be sure ... Checking the condition also would make the check product agnostic again.
Yes, might experiments suggest the same ...
This also affects the other protocol adapters because the handling of the rejected disposition is not device protocol specific.
I think in this case here a localized ServerErrorException should be used, as introduced in #2185 (for #2166).
@calohmn what for? Isn't a 5.03 response adequately describing the issue, i.e. *wait a little and then try again*?
